ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I not only gained insight and skills involving the mechanics of the Italian language, but I also grew immensely as an individual. I learned how to kill my ego in order to learn something I'm not inherently good at, and I became more self-aware of my own strengths and weaknesses within the subject with has directly translated into other areas of my life.
I feel like I perfected the Italian I had learned in ITAL 110 and 120.
I learned how to communicate in Italian

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course is that it is very interactive, everyone is supported regardless of their success that particular day or thus far in the semester, the class becomes a tight knit community in which everyone can stumble through and learn together without fear of judgement, there is constant feedback which allows everyone to get a little bit better every day, and it was incredibly fun which made me excited for class and more eager to learn.  While I know saying this seems naive and false because everything could be improved to some degree, I'm unable to provide any weaknesses in the course. Thinking back there is nothing I wish had gone differently or was disappointed in. It is a really well taught course.
The class is so fun, I am not a language person but I felt very encouraged to participate.

This course mostly feels like a summary of ITAL 110 and 120, which I didn't mind, but I didn't feel like I was learning new things exactly. I did enjoy engaging more with Italian literature/film, though.
It was run extremely well. Michael Farina is an amazing professor. I am so lucky to have had a class with him
Michael was the obvious strength of this course and made it so there were not many weaknesses. Strengths were daily review and approachable and fair assignments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 1000%. It can be incredibly daunting to tackle any new skill, especially a language. The frustration you can feel when you are unable to communicate can be immense (though a good thing to experience so you can relate to others outside the classroom). However, despite all of that, not only is Italian a beautiful language, but it is also taught in a way that is entirely approachable and makes you eager to learn. You will have fun with your classmates, a wonderful relationship with your professor, and honestly, before you know it, you'll be conversing fluidly in Italian and walk out of class realizing you understood everything that was discussed. It is truly empowering, and I would recommend this course to anyone.
Yes, Italian is a great language to learn at Yale
I would recommend Italian to another student, especially if they take it with Professor Farina.
It's a good continuation of ITAL 120, especially if you just want to get your language requirement out of the way.
I would heavily recommend this course to any other students. he is an amazing professor and really engages his students
Yes! A great way to round out your Italian education.
